CAMP FATHER MATHEW,
IN MEMPHIS, TENN., DURING THE YEL-
LOW FEVER EPIDEMIC.

AT the outbreak of the yellow fever in Mem-
phis, Tenn., in August last, Father Wil-
liam Walsh, President of the Father Mathew
Total Abstinence and Benevolent Association
of that city, conceived the idea of establishing
a camp in the suburbs where the members
of the Society, with their families, could find
refuge from the pestilence. A suitable loca-
tion was found, and the camp was established.
Hundreds soon flocked thither to escape the
ravages of the fever in the city, the poor of
all denominations being cordially admitted;
and Father Mathew's Camp was the means of
saving the lives of between four and five hun-
dred people.

The camp was beautifully situated on a no-
ble plateau, embosomed amidst lovely sylvan
scenery. On one side it was shaded by a
forest of stately trees, and on the opposite
side ran a crystal stream, with a bubbling
spring of pure fresh water close by. The
camp represented a miniature city, with its
streets and avenues crossing and intersecting
each other. The two principal streets run-
ning parallel with each other were known as
“Father Mathew Street” and “Father Wil-
liam Street.” These streets were about two
hundred yards in length, and tents to the num-
ber of nearly three hundred, furnished by the
Government, were arranged on each side. In
addition to an immense commissariat depart-
ment--capable of meeting the demands of be-
tween four and five hundred people daily--with
the necessary kitchens, dining-halls, etc., there
were hospitals, drug - stores, reading - rooms,
schools, and a small church established in con-
nection with the camp--all showing the most
admirable thoughtfulness and excellent judg-
ment on the part of the president and mana-
gers. The schools were under the charge of
the Sisters of St. Joseph, who divided their
time between the children and the old folks,
instructing the former and ministering to the
comfort and happiness of the latter. At the
northern end of “Father Mathew Street” was
a little chapel of the Sacred Heart, with a
sacristy on one side and confessional on the
other. This miniature chapel was named
“The Ark.” There Father Walsh celebrated
Mass every morning, after which he went into
the plague-stricken city to minister to the
temporal as well as spiritual wants of the sick
and dying, returning to the camp again at
night. His return was anxiously awaited every
night by the poor people, who feared that he,
like so many of his associate priests, might be
stricken with the disease while in the city. On
his safe return their joy was great; they flocked
around the little “Ark” to hear his words of
consolation and instruction, to recite their
rosary, and to receive, on bended knees, ere
they retired to rest, the benediction of the
Blessed Sacrament.

We publish two illustrations of the camp:
one, the Thanksgiving Mass (the last celebra-
ted at the camp), which shows the people in a
kneeling attitude in front of “The Ark,” and
the priest, Father William Walsh, in the act of
turning round and saluting them with the final
Dominus vobiscum--“The Lord be with you”;
the other scene represents one of the main
streets, just after Mass, as the campers were
preparing to “pull up stakes” and return to
the homes from which they had been driven
by the dread pestilence a few months before.

AN AFTER-DINNER ENTERTAINMENT IN THE PARLOR OF THE HOTEL PASAGE, HAVANA.
EXTERIOR OF THE HOTEL PASAGE.

SITTING-ROOM IN THE TOMANDO CAFÉ.--THE AFTER-DINNER CUP OF COFFEE.
CUBA.--SCENES IN HAVANA.--INCIDENTS OF A WINTER RESIDENCE AT THE CUBAN CAPITAL.--FROM SKETCHES BY WALTER YEAGER.

In a couple of hours after the photographs were
taken the camp was in marching order, and with
the “Ark” in front, filled with little innocents
dressed in white, and guarded by stalwart Father
Mathew men, proceeded down the principal street
of Memphis, towards St. Bridget's Church, where
the Thanksgiving was brought to a close with the
solemn chanting of the “Te Deum.” The little
“Ark” is to be preserved as a Memorial Chapel in
St. Bridget's Church.

It was remarkable that while the fever raged
everywhere around the camp, a single case did not
originate in it. Of eight or nine who died in the
camp each case was contracted in the city. The
camp was a continual source of charity during the
fever, and its benevolence knew no creed or race.
Father Walsh disbursed over twenty-seven thou-
sand dollars independently of generous aid from the
“Citizens' Relief” of Memphis.

Our illustrations are from photographs, copies of
which our readers may order of R. M. Mansford,
Jefferson and Second Streets, Memphis, Tenn., who
has prepared a large number of each, size 8 × 10,
which will be sold at seventy-five cents each for the
benefit of the sufferers, the destitute and orphans,
by the great epidemic.
SCENES IN HAVANA.

OUR first illustration represents the parlor in the
Hotel Pasage, Havana. The sun can gain no
admittance here, but the breeze comes from almost
every direction, caressing the cheek of señor and
señora, caballero and señorita. Everything is
deliciously cool, from
the marble-paved floor
to the cane rocking-
chairs; from the sub-
dued light to the open
windows, through which
comes stealing that pe-
culiar, perfume only to
be inhaled in the tropics.
The parlor is crowded
almost at every hour.
Dark - eyed señoritas,
such as Byron raved
about, attired after the
fashion of old Spain, in
high comb and black
lace, languidly fan them-
selves with genuine Se-
ville fans, with sails like
miniature windmills;
black satin, decorated
with pictures represent-
ing a corrida de toros,
or bull fight, from the
first rush of the mad-
dened bull into the
arena to the last stroke
of the graceful and her-
culean matador. Stately
señoras, watchful as
the traditional dueña--
haughty hidalgos, strong
in lineage and manifold
in name--all lounge,
lean, sit, stand, walk
and gossip in this fra-
grant apartment. A
piano is not wanting,
at which some descend-
ant of the Lady Dulcinea
del Toboso will warble
one of those quaint yet
all melodious ballads so
charmingly adapted to
the guitar and casta-
nets, that measure in
three so marked in poor
Bizet's opera of “Car-
men.” Planters talk
sugarcane, and planters'
wives talk Worth; the
hum of the grand,
prayerful language of Spain drones musically,
while gorgeous tropical flowers add color to a
scene unique, charming, and all-satisfying.
THE EXTERIOR OF THE HOTEL PASAGE.

The exterior of the Hotel Pasage is particularly
striking. The façade is rich in plate-glass and bal-
conies, while statues adorn the coping over the en-
trance. An alameda, or walk, shaded by trees,
stands opposite, beneath which chairs and benches
are placed for the accommodation of the public.
The state apartments are in front and jealously
guarded by closely drawn blinds during the reign
of old King Sol; but in the early morning and at
dewy eve these are thrown open, while the guests,
in the coolest of possible toilets, lounge on the
balconies, chatting, smoking and inhaling the per-
fume-laden breeze, The alameda, too, is thronged
by a gay and animated crowd, which passes like a
living, moving wave. The gilded youth of the
island affect the Pasage, and, standing at its por-
tals, pay the tribute of a stare to the charms of the
Cuban belles.
THE TOMANDO CAFE.

This café is much frequented by the upper tendom
of the island, who stroll in for a gossip, a cigarette,
an ice and a cooling drink. Its open doors are
guarded by sentinels in the shape of prickly cacti,
the pineapple “on its native heath,” or the dwarf
palm, American rocking chairs are placed “all in a
row” opposite the doorways, and their occupants
rock to a measure that almost amounts to a lullaby,
or a cradle-song. The swarthy attendants, attired in
the snowiest of white,
anticipate every want;
while the habitués have
no necessity to issue
orders, their wishes
being forestalled. A
cooler apartment than
this does not exist on
the island, while its
“fixins” actually sug-
gest, say a temperature
of sixty degrees. Here
is to be found the much
coveted, much sought
for Diario de la Ma-
rina, a newspaper
which is to the Cubans
what the Koran is to
the followers of the Pro-
phet, with many other
journals, FRANK LESLIE'S
ILLUSTRATED NEWSPA-
PER included, and pe-
riodicals. Every visitor
to Havana “does” the
Tomando café, and does
well.
